{{book |title=Rehabilitations and Other Essays | image = Rehabilitations and Other Essays.jpg |author=[[C.S. Lewis]] |publisher=Oxford University Press |date=[[1939]] |format=Hardcover with dust jacket |pages= |}} '''''Rehabilitations and Other Essays''''' is a collection of essays by [[C.S. Lewis]]. The essay "The Alliterative Metre" includes a mention of an unpublished text by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]: "Professor Tolkien will soon, I hope, be ready to publish an alliterative poem". It remains unknown to which poem Lewis is referring, although suggestions have included "[[The Fall of Arthur]]", "[[The Homecoming of Beorhtnoth Beorhthelm's Son]]", "[[The Lay of the Children of Húrin]]", or poems included in ''[[The Legend of Sigurd and Gudrún]]''. The essay also includes a poem (p. 122) about himself and Tolkien "in a Berkshire bar" where they meet a man claiming to have seen a [[dragons|dragon]].[[Jason Fisher]], "[http://lingwe.blogspot.com/2010/03/before-tolkiens-unexpected-party.html Before Tolkien’s unexpected party, an unexpected reference]" (dated 29 March 2010) at [http://lingwe.blogspot.com/ Lingwë - Musings of a Fish (blog)] (accessed 15 May 2011)The poem reads as:
''We were talking of dragons, Tolkien and I''
''In a Berkshire bar. The big workman''
''Who had sat silent and sucked his pipe''
''All the evening, from his empty mug''
''With gleaming eye glanced towards us;''
''‘I seen ’em myself’, he said fiercely.'' Tolkien commented on the poem in his [[letter 300]]. ==See also== *''[[Selected Literary Essays]]'' {{references|note}} {{title|italics}} [[Category:Books by C.S. Lewis]] [[Category:Publications by title]] [[Category:Scholarly books]]
